item.content:encoded: Here are some projects I am working on: georgeredinger.github.com

item.title: Ch 2: Today's Date: 1 E.C.E. ... Hot, Flat and Crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 2 describes the 5  key problems that are intensified by the world being Hot, Flat and Crowded. They are:
  1. Growing demand for ever scarcer energy and natural resources
  2. Transfer of wealth to petro-dictators
  3. Disruptive climate change
  4. Energy poverty
  5. Bio-diversity loss
Which of the three trends--hot,flat,crowded--cause which of the 5 problems and how do they interact? [caption id="attachment_51" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Causes-->Effects"][/caption] How does solving the problems influence the the trends? What is causing the 3 trends? What are  the root causes? The growth  of the middle class results from increased productivity, which  causes an increase in income, causing an  increase in consumption, which results in increased scarcity in products whose production has not kept pace with the overall increase in productivity, which causes energy poverty for those below the middle class, since they are crowded out of the energy market. Friedman, so far, has not indicated any feed back loops in his model. Oil is an increasingly scarce resource and transferring wealth to petro-dictators is a problem? As scarcity increases, prices rise. As prices rise, substitution increases, decreasing the transfer of wealth to petro-dictators. So, how can rich petro-dictators be a long term problem? Likewise for petroleum's contribution to disruptive climate change--Coal is another story. What feedback might the 3 trends and 5 problems have on population growth? [caption id="attachment_48" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Is there already feedback between Flat and Crowded?"] Friedman's data show (project) a decrease in population growth from the time of his birth to 2050. The International Data Base of the U.S. Census Bureau shows the peak in population growth rate to have passed in the 1960s. I don't have data for the change in economic production/consumption for that time period.
In order for the middle class to increase, there must be a transfer from the upper class to the middle, or there must be  growth in production/consumption  greater than  growth in population. This source  shows world GDP growth in the neighborhood of 4%. Compare that with a population growth rate near 1% and falling. To my thinking, this puts GDP growth as the key causal factor of  the 5 problems.
In summary,
[/caption]
One Friedman's  three trends is already in decline--population growth.
One of the problems--Petro-dictators--is self limiting. It declines faster, the faster the  trends and problems get worse. I hope Friedman will solve more of the problems and reverse more trends in upcoming chapters. http://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpopinfo.html

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Obviously, what a wonderful internet site and informative posts, I'll add backlink - bookmark this site? Regards, Reader.

item.title: Ch 3: Our Carbon Copies … Hot, Flat and Crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded: In chapter 3 Friedman down plays the crowded part of "Hot, Flat and Crowded" and plays up the flat part. Has Friedman put "Crowded" in the title as a straw man? Something that he can knock down to make his point that it's not the number of people in the world that matter, but rather, what they do? Does the good storytelling  so far suggest more such devices will be used? here are a couple of references, in case--like me--you need  to be reminded of some of the tools of the trade: [caption id="attachment_78" align="alignright" width="153" caption="This dog don't hunt"][/caption] Literary Devices Rhetorical Devices

item.title: Ch 4: Fill 'Er Up with Dictators … Hot, Flat and Crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 4 links the decline of freedom with the rising price of crude oil. Friedman calls it the first law of Petropolitics This chart, from the Department of Energy, shows a trend of increasing oil production costs. [caption id="" align="alignright" width="440" caption="less oil now costs more to produce (http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/perfpro/fig16.htm)"][/caption] This article (Forbes) claims that OPEC is in panic mode because at $70 per barrel the price of oil is below "marginal cost of production" This article (Reuters) suggests that somewhere between todays $70 and the July's $147 per barrel price of crude oil, lies substitution of coal-to-liquid based fuels for petroleum based ones. That's Bad news for the petro-dictators. Friedman uses the price of oil as the variable controlling  the level of freedom in petro-dictatorships. Profits would be a better index to have used. Because production costs are rising,  price increases  must pay for both rising production costs and profits. Worse still, for the petro-dictators, fuel substitution and conservation both increase as price increases. Coal-to-Liquids is not good news for climate change.  Since burning oil releases less CO2 per unit of energy than Coal. Friedman points to Bahrain as an example of an oil producer seeing shrinking future profits and acting to move toward political and economic reform. Are Bahrainians extra smart? In the long run petro-dictatorships are self limiting. As Keynes famously said.
“In the long run, we're all dead.”
When fighting several fires, knowing which direction they are headed, and which will burn them selves out and when is valuable.

item.title: Ch5: Global Weirding ... Hot,Flat and Crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
For those who have been reading along, and want to cut to the chase, here are a couple of audio presentations  that summarize Hot, Flat and Crowded. This one (a "living on earth" episode) is a short interview with Friedman about the book. And This one a longer talk, about an hour giving a detailed run through of the book. Warning: no Science was harmed (or, used even) in the preparation of this post. On page 129 Friedman says he has given up the [BBC] World Service for the Weather Channel. That may be why he quotes this AP story from December 11, 2007 about the Northwest passage being open for "the first time in recorded history" when the BBC reported on  September 10, 2000 here "A Canadian police patrol boat has completed a voyage through the fabled Northwest Passage without encountering any pack ice" [caption id="attachment_141" align="alignright" width="297" caption="Canadian Police Patrol Boat St Roch II"][/caption] What's up with that? Wikipedia has an article "recording" the history of the northwest passage with the details. Even the New York Times--surely Friedman reads it--ran a piece on it in 2000 (you can Google that one for your self) In my first post about Hot,Flat and crowded I suggested that the book might be more about feelings than facts. This chapter  confirms this and takes it to a higher level--using reputation to influence the feelings of others. If you desire support for an important project, but are having difficulty getting others on board, one tactic is to use your reputation or authority or that of allies to influence others. Here are some examples:
Dick Cheney, Vice President "Simply stated, there is no doubt that Saddam Hussein now has weapons of mass destruction." Aug. 26, 2002
Gen. Tommy Franks: "There is no doubt that the regime of Saddam Hussein possesses weapons of mass destruction. As this operation continues, those weapons will be identified, found, along with the people who have produced them and who guard them." Mar. 22, 2003 For bureaucratic reasons, we settled on one issue, weapons of mass destruction [as justification for invading Iraq] because it was the one reason everyone could agree on. - Paul Wolfowitz, Vanity Fair interview May 28, 2003
"We know that he has stored secret supplies of biological and chemical weapons throughout his country." -- Al Gore, Sept. 23, 2002
We have recently seen how effective high level worrying  can be when the Secretary of the Treasury,Federal Reserve Chairman and the President publicly worried about the impending doom that would befall us all if we did not take action. The common enemy,lack of "liquidity", had to be  stopped. Like it or not, we got big government action and we got it fast. It seems that this is the role of Hot,Flat and Crowded. When a respected, puzzler prize winning author publicly proclaims his fears, we too may become fearful enough to take action. The facts are of only secondary importance. The important thing is for thought leaders to be scared. Scared enough for the rest of us to follow. To paraphrase FDR: "We have nothing to fear except the lack of fear it's self" Why worry when... You can get a house Here that can move to higher ground as the sea level rises: [caption id="attachment_146" align="alignright" width="190" caption="What? Me Worry?"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_127" align="alignnone" width="296" caption="Birds Migrate with the seasons, why not people? Wait,... the well healed already do..."][/caption] Why not just manipulate the Weather in the direction we want ? Or,why not make the Earths atmosphere reflect more heat from the sun?
There are ominous signs that the Earth’s weather patterns have begun to change dramatically and that these changes may portend a drastic decline in food production – with serious political implications for just about every nation on Earth. The drop in food output could begin quite soon, perhaps only 10 years from now. The regions destined to feel its impact are the great wheat-producing lands of Canada and the U.S.S.R. in the North, along with a number of marginally self-sufficient tropical areas – parts of India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Indochina and Indonesia – where the growing season is dependent upon the rains brought by the monsoon. --Newsweek April 28,1975
...As we’ve worked through this period of market turmoil, we have acted on a case-by-case basis — addressing problems at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, working with market participants to prepare for the failure of Lehman Brothers, and lending to AIG so it can sell some of its assets in an orderly manner. We have also taken a number of powerful tactical steps to increase confidence in the system, including a temporary guaranty program for the U.S. money market mutual fund industry. These steps have been necessary but not sufficient.--Guess who More is needed. We saw market turmoil reach a new level last week, and spill over into the rest of the economy. We must now take further, decisive action to fundamentally and comprehensively address the root cause of this turmoil. ...--Somebody else Finally, my favorite: So-called “global warming” is just a secret ploy by wacko tree-huggers to make America energy independent, clean our air and water, improve the fuel efficiency of our vehicles, kick-start 21st-century industries, and make our cities safer and more livable. Don’t let them get away with it! –Chip Giller

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yesterday I received the Fall/Winter issue of "Woodland NOTES" http://www.cnr.uidaho.edu/extforest/Vol.%2020_No.%201.pdf From the University of Idaho. The front page story is titled: "Payments for Forest Carbon Sequestration". By the time U of I extension publishes an article about a topic, it is no longer cutting edge. In a discussion of this chapter, someone said "Friedman is a sissy". The meaning of this comment was that Friedman was bringing up safe mainstream ideas. Friedman is not a thought leader but a follower. Michael Crichton predicts this in his speech called "Complexity Theory and Environmental Management" http://www.crichton-official.com/speech-complexity.html According to Crichton, problem popularizers are consistently behind the curve, pleading that we should respond to problems that have already turned around.

item.title: Religious Wars, right here at home
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded: Things are getting so bad, even heaven is going to the dogs.

item.title: Ch6: The age of Noah, Hot,Flat and crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
In the previous chapter --global weirding--Friedman touched on adaption as a way to cope with hot flat and crowded. This chapter is about those species that fail to adapt. Humans are an adaptable species... [caption id="attachment_161" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Asian Baby Mop, adaption of the Asian Mat Rat"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_160" align="alignleft" width="258" caption="Euro Baby Mop, adaption of Euro Rug Rat"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_163" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Partners in co-evolution don't always evolve at the same rate "][/caption] According to the hygiene hypotheses repeated adaption leads to the development of a more robust species, a virtuous cycle of improvements to the species. The effects on other less robust species is being studied. Species that have long exposure to stable, isolated environments  become hyper specialized and become increasingly dependent on specialized co-evolutions.  Witness the effects of introductions of outside species into once isolated islands in the South Pacific, Australia and New Zealand. North and South American indigenous peoples where decimated by the--mostly--unintentional introduction of Smallpox from Europe. Humans are an adaptable species, we seem to exude a toxin that suppresses competitive species. Some plants produce Phytotoxins to suppress the growth  competing plants in their environment. Fungi do it with Myotoxins.  Still other species of plants and animals operate in ways that enhance the variety and  growth  of other species. [caption id="attachment_164" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Some adaptions are as much social as physiological "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_167" align="alignnone" width="187" caption="Some ecosystem services come from the built environment "][/caption]
Learning is not compulsory... neither is survival. W. Edwards Deming [caption id="attachment_165" align="aligncenter" width="122" caption="We Have Met the Enemy and He Is Us"][/caption]
A human being should be able to change a diaper, plan an invasion, butcher a hog, conn a ship, design a building, write a sonnet, balance accounts, build a wall, set a bone, comfort the dying, take orders, give orders, cooperate, act alone, solve equations, analyze a new problem, pitch manure, program a computer, cook a tasty meal, fight efficiently, die gallantly. Specialization is for insects. -Robert A. Heinlein

item.title: Ch7: Energy Poverty, Hot,Flat and Crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
In this chapter Friedman  links  energy with wealth. [caption id="" align="alignleft" width="252" caption="Cheap electrons sprout like mushrooms in my back yard. That's why I'm so innovative"][/caption]No doubt about it, it's easier to do stuff with cheap electrons. Reading at night, working long hours 'cause you can see what you are doing. Running 3, 8 hour shifts, or 2, 12 hour ones is possible. In 1976, my  chemistry professor told his students that oil was too valuable to burn for fuel. Oil, he said, should be used instead, to make stuff, including food, while Nuclear power should be used to make electricity. The French seem to have taken his advice. At least  his advice about  Nuclear power. Friedman sounds like  cornucopian Julian Simon who argued that the ultimate resource is us humans. According to Friedman, just give 'um cheap electrons and they will innovate.  Another cornucopian, Buckminster Fuller, wrote in 1969 in his Operating manual for space ship earth,
"The fossil fuel deposits of our Spaceship Earth correspond to our automobile's storage battery which must be conserved to turn over our main engine's self-starter."

item.title: Ch10: The Energy Internet--Hot,Flat and crowded
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded: A primary tenet of neoclassical economics is that producers and consumers act rationally with perfect  information. There are a couple of practical problems with this idea. One is the lack of information and reward for acting on it. If energy prices--as billed to the consumer--varied during the day, reflecting the variations in production cost, consumers could modulate their energy usage accordingly. If only they had the information and the tools. This is the crux of the so called "Smart Grid". "Smart Grid" is  a misnomer though, because it's not so much that the grid is smart, but the end points on the grid--electricity producers and consumers-- are, by both knowing the supply,demand and price at the same time they make decisions about production and consumption. This fulfills all the prerequisites for  neoclassical economic functioning, except the rational producer and consumer part. That part cannot be supplied by installation of new equipment  at the points of  electricity production and consumption. That part must be installed in the heads of the producers and consumers. In the UK they use a radio link--195 khz--to broadcast electricity price information to smart meters. These meters will turn off some electrical loads when the price rises. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_teleswitch Their are many competing so called Smart-Grid systems, all have the goal of implementing Demand response electricity management. Other markets have undergone dramatic changes as a result of the connection  of information on supply, demand and price between buyer and seller. Ebay.com, Amazon.com and the various travel booking sites are examples of what happens when supply and demand information flows freely. There are a few anomalies in the perfect machine of rational actors, acting with perfect information. Here is one recent story of a malfunctioning "Energy Internet": For residents of Ontario Canada, the energy internet is in place today: From http://techdirt.com/articles/20081112/1845132812.shtml An online service that seeks to connect car drivers with passengers has had it's operations  restricted in Ontario   because the local bus company complained.  The service, PickupPal matches drivers and passengers, saving fuel and reducing traffic. Trouble is, if somebody who was going to take the bus, decides instead--because of  new, more perfect internet information--, to ride with someone that was  driving there anyway, the bus company losses a customer. That's unfair competition, says the  bus company.  If you are tempted to think this type of thing is a recent phenomenon , read  Frédéric Bastiat's Candlemakers Petition from 1830. We are used to thinking that oil producers will use their influence on government to improve their competitive position.  What will it be like when we have many sources of energy all vying for advantage. Now we have 2 party system, Coal and Oil against The Alternatives. What will it be like when, wind;solar; photovoltaic;solar thermal;geothermal; ocean wave;tidal;hydro;nuclear;cellulose ethanol; corn ethanol;cane ethanol;gopher gas;... are all vying for advantage.  Not technical  advantage, political advantage. Subsidies, rebates, endorsements, publicly funded pilot projects etc.  Energy source Balkanization seems inevitable once the hegemony  of oil passes.  Each player will have a pitch as to why their flavor of electrons better serves the public interest. And why the others should be suppressed. The tradition for energy company's lacking a breakthrough innovation  is to "piss in Uncle Sam's pocket" to gain  advantage. To perform this maneuver, the company must be very close indeed to Uncle Sam. Uncle gets the warm  feeling that comes from serving the public interest  and the energy company gets the relief it needs.

item.title: Modern Science Writing: The Mysterious Universe
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded: This post kicks off a new book, "The Oxford book of modern Science Writing" edited by Richard Dawkins. It's a book of "extracts and short pieces from a variety of scientific works from the early 20th century on." Or as Dawkins says: "This is a collection of good writing by professional scientists, not excursions into science by professional writers." (Sniff) The first extract is from James Jean's book, "The Mysterious Universe" [caption id="attachment_267" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Sir James Hopwood Jeans"][/caption] In this excerpt--all of 1 page out of 150 pages of the full text--Sir James paraphrases Huxley's story about the ability of 6 monkeys, given typewriters and millions of years, to produce sonnets. Is Dawkins a typing monkey, selecting excerpts in place of keys? The monkey makes meaning by repeatedly striking 1 of 40 odd keys. Considering that a sonnet contains only 14 lines of text, Dawkins has set himself a comparatively more difficult task. He has selected 1 page out of the possible 150 in Jeans's original text. Does having more keys to choose from make meaning making easier? Us modern monkeys need only one click here and a sonnet will be generated by something with less intelligence than a monkey. Those who wish to compare "real" sonnets with the automatic ones should go here According to this Wikipedia article, a chimp called Noam Chimpski had a vocabulary of about 125 "words". My not too careful analysis of Shakespeare's sonnets shows them to have less than 100 unique words each. So "Monkeys" writing sonnets seems plausible. Acording to this article, Dr Sue Savage-Rumbaugh shows chimps are able to have lucid conversations with humans. (compare that with a city council meeting) In the article, Kanzi the chimp is quoted as saying 'I write, give grape'. It seems chimp poets have much in common with human ones. Poetry for wine goes back at least to Homer. so some people think it is stupid i thought it will be interesting to others in this poem i have followed a wide ellipse as a form of self study harmonious figures produce deep mirror resonances the ear can see lined up i also spent summers at camp stendhal camp manzoni camp dickens embracing the globe italians multiply the earth with their antiquity people go on about their fathermothers and grandmotherfathers on the hood a silver woman colossus pointed her firm silver breasts at the wind san francesco taught them to taste and know the sweetness in every breath of life tactically watch weather phenomena wash away sand in watery waves wait a minute they ask me where are you going now please tell us the voices move in many directions like great tribes of fish in the gulf stream i can only suggest it by placing one state against another offering plots where living humans become mahogany boxes in that police state i hold myself prisoner to childhood

item.title: Modern Science Writing: Just Six Numbers
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
There's more than one law of attraction, the two considered here are the one that holds the little things together and the one that keeps the big things from drifting apart. [caption id="attachment_318" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Sir Martin Rees "][/caption] It has been said that it is the strength of weak ties explains the functioning of society. There are economists who specialize in "Macro" and others in "Micro". There are micro biologists and macro. There are the good the bad and the ugly. we seem happy to explain  how things work with differing rules for differing scales. Otherwise there would be simply a single Economics and Biology, with a single explanation applying at all scales. This chapter, from The Oxford book of modern science writing, is an excerpt from Martin Rees book, "Just Six Numbers". Wikipedia describes each of the Six: * ν, Nu: the ratio of the fine structure constant, and the gravitational coupling constant defined using two electrons. These dimensionless constants are the respective coupling constants for the electroweak force and gravitation (circa ≈1043); * ε, Epsilon: related to the strong force; * ω, Omega: the number of electrons and protons in the observable universe (circa 1080); * Λ, Lambda: the cosmological constant; * Q: a ratio of fundamental energies; * δ, Delta: the number of spatial dimensions. ν, Nu is number discussed in the excerpt. The discussion is concerned with "strides toward explaining the universe". I am all for explaining the universe. But I have, what seem to me, to be more pressing concerns. Like, why can't we just get along? At what point do multi-purpose tools cross over, to become useless ones. Is a jack of all trades really the master of none? It seems that some design patterns hold together better than others. We detect   them as patterns simply because they are still together, after all these years. Are all persistent patterns  "good" simply because the resist decomposition? DDT? The electoral college? Classical Music? Microsoft Windows?  Many objects and institutions hold together despite their apparent dysfunction. [caption id="attachment_329" align="alignright" width="262" caption="Multi Functional? "][/caption] Us humans seem to have a habit of gluing things together that would not stick without our aid. Taoisum advises that we recognize the scale of the forces we encounter and "go with the flow". Western civilization seems to think otherwise. Sir Martin Rees sees this as Our Final Hour. Is he correct? Will our failure to comprehend the scale of the forces we attempt to manipulate lead to our doom? I have loosened up the comment policy, in an attempt to get some feedback. I would like to hear what you think. Is Walmart too large, are small scale retailers more appropriate? Why? Is local, small scale food production better than centralized large scale production? Why? Is large scale centralized consumption (cities) better than small scale diffuse consumption? (suburbs) Why? Are there natural best sizes for human activities? :
  • Family size
  • Government Size
  • Bus,vs Train, vs car, vs bicycle
  • Monogamy vs polygamy
  • Amazon.com vs the corner book store
  • Boxers vs Briefs
  • Housing Rent vs Buy
  • Housing duplex vs single family
  • Housing megaplex vs double wide

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I found this:
These six numbers constitute a ‘recipe’ for a universe. Moreover, the outcome is sensitive to their values: if any one of them were to be ‘untuned’, there would be no stars and no life.
Here: http://www.ichthus.info/BigBang/Docs/Just6num.pdf This implies that there is an objective answer to the Boxers or Briefs question. The answer depends on how well tuned the garment is to the scale of the individual.

item.title: Modern Science Writing: Creation Revisited
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
This chapter is an excerpt from Peter Atkins book "Creation Revisited" , "Why Things Change"
Water runs downhill,  payday's on Friday
It has been said that these two facts are the essential qualifications for a good plumber.  To qualify as a Thermodynamicist it seems to be:
Most Water runs downhill, payday's  uncertain
Merging the two professions, we end up with the Ram Pump:

This one you have to click on to see the animation. Merge Thermodynamics with the desire for status and comfort and we end up with this, an elegant solution to the problem of converting a lot of concentrated energy into a little bit of comfort and even less style: This process of using energy to reorganize matter is sometimes called Life. Sometimes it's just a water pump. For some, it's Art, for others, it's rearranging the deck chairs on the titanic. Sisyphus offended the Gods by his cleverness. He maintained his status and comfort via creative exploitation of them. Being Gods, they eventually caught up with him. His punishment: [flashvideo file=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K5MdFdAe_JY /] Are we more than a thermodynamic process?

item.title: Back saver
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I saw Mark Havel demonstrate a  LogRite Jr arch in September at the Bonner County Woods day, sponsored by the Idaho Forest Owners Association, IFOA and hosted on the D'Aoust compound property near Clark Fork, Idaho. Wanting one, but not wanting to pay $540 for it, I copied Mark's design. To understand why this is such a neat tool, watch the movie here  Jr Arch. Here is my version of Mark Havel's design: If someone wants to build one of these, I will annotate this photo with dimensions. This is the situation that is solved so well with this tool. I have cut though a tree, but it is hung up on other nearby trees. The C-clamps hold the handle to the arch while I decide if the fulcrum is at just the right place. No tractors, cables, chains or come-alongs needed, hangup solved in  under 1 minute. My first tree, moved on wheels to the truck  rather than dragged or cut up and carried piece by piece. My second tree, much larger than the first, the heaver the tree the more wheels help. Loaded up, ready to go with energy left for splitting and stacking. Next steps:
  • drill the handle mounts and bolt  to the arch.
  • fit the end of the handle with a tee grip like the commercial version has.
Lessons Learned:
  • Use lighter material. The commercial version uses 0.090 wall thickness. The local steel supplier only had 0.120, this means extra weight. Not a big problem until I'm lifting it into the back of the truck.
  • About 1/2 of the cost of building a little arch like this is the cost of the skidding tongs. So my first try was to substitute a chain with a slip hook for the log tongs. The piece of round pipe seen where the tongs are attached has a slot cut in it to grab  the chain, so the chain can be wrapped around the log and hooked in the slot. After a few tries with the chain, it became clear the the tongs where worth the money.
  • The tongs are expensive, ~$100, so I made  my arch so they can be quickly removed for use in another application. The commercial arch has them  permanently    attached.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hello! Thank you very much for that enlightening article

Hi, I was searching for a log arch plan and I found your post on your blog. You done a very good job with your Back saver. You were offering on a picture to give dimensions of metal pieces you used to build it… I would be very interested to build one too. Could it be possible to send me these informations?
Have a nice day and happy new year,
Olivier

item.title: Split-O-Matic
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
[flashvideo file="wp-content/uploads/2009/11/ChopOMatic.FLV" image="wp-content/uploads/2009/11/ChopOMatic.jpg" /] I got the idea for the Split-O-Matic from here: vipukirves Split-O-Matic hints and tips:
  • The video shows an easy to split piece of white pine, difficult to split logs are still difficult. The big time savings comes from the log staying put during the splitting
  • If the diameter of the log is close to the inside diameter of the tire, after splitting it may expand enough to be difficult to remove the pieces.  Now you have a justification for  keeping those junk tires of various sizes around.
  • A small log may fly out of the tire after the first hit. To solve this, put several small logs in the tire.
  • The danger to your shins of a miss is small, hitting the tire damages nothing, except maybe your ego if you have an audience.
  • You get some of the energy back on the bounce, at the bottom of the stroke, the handle hits the tire and bounces back.
  • Your stroke has a lower limit--the height of the tire. So you only have to swing the maul up from at worst that height.
  • I would do better to have my splitting block a little higher and have a larger diameter block, that way I could use a larger tire for larger logs.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi With the VEVERAXE the splitting is even easier because there is no fear to break the handle because it will always remain ON THE BLOCK. You will not get any concusion to your hands either because you can hold the handle very gently at the end of the strike. Observe the longest chopper block of the world and the first rotating chopper block in the world. www.vipukirves.fi/english/vipukirves_videos.htm Best Regards Heikki, the inventor

item.title: Creating Franken Fork
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded: What do you get when you cross a Dura-Fork with a Wonder-Fork? [flashvideo file="wp-content/uploads/2009/11/FrankenFork.flv" image="wp-content/uploads/2009/11/FrankenFork.jpg" /] If it was truly durable, they wouldn't have to call it a Dura-Fork. The welder is from here.  If link no longer works, it's a Harbor Freight plastic welder. A stream of air is passed over an electric heater, out a nozzle making a stream hot enough to melt the plastic so it can be squished together.  These "barn forks" are made from polycarbonate, so that's an air temperature in the neighborhood of 500 F by the time the stream exits the nozzle and hits the plastic. Not a temperature suitable for drying your hair or nails. The welder costs about $35, a new fork about $15. I had 4 broken forks, I sacrificed  one for parts to fix the other 3. WooHoo, $10  saved on my first use and I get to keep the tool. More importantly I have 3 extra forks for possible helpers.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The welded on tines seem to hold up as well as the others. Old, used forks may break tines more often than new forks. Maybe, the repeated flexing fatigues the tines.

item.title: Predictably Irrational, intro and how the book was choosen
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
This post kicks of reading  "Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions" by Dan Ariely. The obvious question is: how  was the decision made to read this book?  More specificity how did the "group" make the decision? Since I'm part of a group that discusses and sometimes reads books. People brought various books to a meeting, each book bringer in turn gave a pitch as to why the group should discuss and possibly read the books they brought to the meeting. Then,  an apparently rational process of voting took place, and the winner was,  ahem, predictably irrational. This book is possibly the only one of the presented choices whose title can be used to justify it's reading.

item.title: Predictably Irrational Ch1: The Truth About Relativity
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
The Truth about Relativity

Why Everything Is Relative--Even When It Shouldn't Be
Chapter 1 of Predictably Irrational is about measurement standards.
She asks: "Do these pants make my butt look big?". He answers: "Compared to what?" Possible comparisons:
  • Last week, her own butt
  • J-Lo's butt
  • [caption id="attachment_500" align="alignright" width="119" caption="Jill"][/caption] Jill's butt:
  • Your butt
Possible Answers:
  • No
  • Yes
  • Absolutely not
  • Other
You don't have to read  chapter one to know that none of these is the correct answer. For those who know someone whose butt is not just the right size, there are exercises to Increase or to Decrease it's relative size. I can think of only one measurement--social or otherwise--that does not depend on some other measurement as an anchor.
  • The Fahrenheit temperature scale originality used 100 as human body temperature and the temperature of an icy brine solution as 0.
  • The Celsius scale uses the freezing point of water for 0 and the boiling point as 100
  • Gravity is measured relative to the Earth.
  • Distance is relative to some long dead kings foot. Which was 12 thumb widths long.
  • 1 Meter is the distance that light travels in 1/299792458th of a second
  • Light travels at a rate of 299792458  meters  per second
  • The international poverty line is $1.08 at 1993 purchasing-power parity
  • In the United states the poverty line is $10,830 (2008)
Our anchors  have more in common with the sea anchors pictured at the  left  than with the bottom anchors pictured at the top of this post.
Do the measurement anchors used in the physical sciences hold firmer  than those used by social scientists? Is the poverty line more rational than the Fahrenheit scale? Is 350 ppm CO2 absolutely or relatively good? Are some measurement standards decoys, designed by their proponents to  manipulate our behaviour? Measurement anchors for the physical sciences are published by NIST. For those looking for the social science  anchors, here's one for the Butt. Other social science anchors are buried deep in the mud.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Jeff. Agreed,
The author of "Predictably Irrational" seems to be making the case that humans have some intrinsic biases when it comes to judgment about quantities.
The hard sciences', counter measure to this bias is to remove human judgment from the measurement. The soft sciences--as you point out--include feelings about quantities. Quality (value) is important in the soft sciences, hard science has only quantity.
C.P. Snow alluded to this issue in his "The Two Cultures" lecture in 1959:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Two_Cultures

I agree that all measures are "relative", but I can't help but feel that you are blurring multiple kinds of "relative" into one bucket.
In the modern physical sciences, the definitions of the base units depend upon the measurement of some physical quantity, and all other units are exactly defined from those base units (e.g. we use the speed of light in a vacuum, oscillations of a cesium-60 atom, and a bock of metal in a safe to anchor our definitions of the meter, the second, and the kilogram).
But these units make no statements such as good or bad; they are just values calibrated against a scale.
This seems quite unlike the poverty line or if CO2 levels are too high, in that in these cases people are assigning arbitrary criteria as to where a line should be drawn in the sand, leaving a lot of argument for the *value* of the quantity in no matter the unit chosen. In other words, the value itself is NOT well anchored in anything.
In contrast, basic physical quantities like absolute zero, the speed of light, and the critical density of the universe, exist completely independent of the units, with the value in the being very well anchored, but with some error introduced by our ability to measure the quantity.
Without making the differentiation between intrinsically defined quantities and arbitrarily defined quantities, it seems to put some fundamentally defined quantities on the same level as those that have been "felt out" by academics, and leads to a slippery slope in which distrust of--or overconfidence in--some quantities leads to overall distrust of--or overconfidence in--all the quantities.

item.title: Predictably Irrational Ch2: The Fallacy of Supply and Demand
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_580" align="alignleft" width="154" caption="A Fallacy?"][/caption] The subtitle of this chapter  is: "Why the Price of Pearls--and Everything Else--Is Up in the Air." It would seem from the title of this chapter that it was going to be about Supply and Demand and how they where a fallacy. The subtitle suggests that this is  maybe a chapter about price "irrationality". It seems to me that chapter two is about a third kind of "irrationality". Taste. Zappos--an on-line shoe retailer--carries 126,038 styles of shoes. It seems that individual taste varies.  Producers attempt and sometimes succeed in manipulating consumers tastes. Consumers attempt and sometimes succeed in purchasing more of what they prefer. Ariely complains that "...we can't rely on the market forces of supply and demand to set optimal market prices". "Optimal Market Prices"? For who?  To what end?  Why?  If we are willing to suggest that  there is an optimum preference for Zappos shoe style 126,038, then it is perfectly rational for there to be a optimal demand and hence an optimal  price.  The fallacy, it seems to me, it the idea that a dynamic system, such as the  complex web of shoe  producers, distributors,retailers and consumers, has an optimum and that we should seek it out.

item.title: Full Vigor Forestry: Chapter 1
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_535" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Ronald Coase"][/caption] This is the first installment of  my commentary on the book "Full Vigor Forestry: Sustainable Forest Management from the Forest Owner's Point of View", second edition (2003) by Jim Birkemeier. The book appears to be self published , as it has no ISBN.  The authors web page is http://www.timbergreenforestry.com/ Chapter one starts out with "...a new and separate timber market, designed to meet the needs of the woodlot owner, and treat them with respect." This chapter makes the argument that the small forest owner  is being exploited by the current timber market.  The author promises that the book will explain how the small forest owner can achieve their goals while  facing market pressure. These ideas seem similar to those of Ronald Coase. Coase's theorem says that economic externalities will be efficiently handled by a market that assigns individual property rights to them. According to the Family Forest Research Center , about 35 percent of forest land in the United States is owned by small owners.  The book is aimed at this group of owners. A key concept in Coase's theorem is that of transaction costs. In a world with no transaction costs there would be no need for large organizations to supply the goods and services that we consume. In such a world,  consumers  would  have access to products with out the friction of things like sales taxes, searching, shopping, or  sales commissions.  Producers  would know what consumers wanted,  when  and where to deliver it, at what price. Then there are those pesky externalities. Air pollution, water pollution, airport noise, traffic jams,lines at the checkout, soil erosion, invasive species, dirty laundry,etc..  Coase's argument is that if each thing has an owner  and those owners  act in their own best interest, they will act to  keep their "golden goose" in good health. So it is with forestry.  Who bears the cost of  forestry practices? Who reaps the rewards?  When the bearers and reapers  are one and the same--according to Coase--there are no externalities. If good forestry is complex, requiring many specialists and  expensive equipment, it will also require large organizations.  In this environment, little guys pay more and are paid less for the same commodity than the big guys. This article from Inland Forest Management hints that the Coasian floor for saw mills has been rising, a few large mills and  owners, replacing many smaller ones. This trend would seem to result in more market power for large saw mills and less for small forest owners. It seems that  Jim Birkemeier  has a plan to lower the Coasian floor of forestry, improving efficiency while reducing externalities. I'll be reporting on the remaining chapters. Stay tuned.
http://www.familyforestresearchcenter.org/faq.html#q2

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: As a comment on Jim Birkemeiers book and the Coase theorem, it is noteworthy that Jim spent many years as a commercial forester, finding in his own gut the feelings that the landowner gets next to nothing and the land is ravaged, when engaged with the larger industry around them.

item.title: Full Vigor Forestry: Chapter 2
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
Chapter Two of "Full Vigor Forestry" answers the question: "What is a Full Vigor Forest"? Chapter one argues that resources are most productivity managed when long term consequences of   management  choices  are borne by the managers.  More colorfully, Mr Birkemeier argues for a shift  from an "Eat what you can  kill" to a "Eat what you can grow" mindset. Aesop's fable, warning not to kill the goose seems  not to be being heeded by small forest  owners. My interpretation of Jim Birkemeier's  "Full Vigor' concept is that  a forest at "Full Vigor " is one that is operating at the green dot on the above curve. This assumes that "volume" is  the only thing of value produced by the forest and there is no difference in management cost between this point and any other. The point is, what ever we are producing, we want to "operate" our forest at the point where it produces the most of it. Further, we are managing for the long term and feel the effect of externalities,so  we implicitly consider  the many factors besides how long to let each tree grow before harvesting it. Here's a short list of "other factors":
  • harvest cost for various regimes
  • impact on non wood products,mushrooms, berries, carbon capture...
  • current and predicted future markets for each product
    • fuel wood vs pulp vs others
    • current saw-log market by species
    • current specialty product markets
  • current cash needs
  • government incentives
    • taxes
    • subsidies
    • cost shares
    • prohibited practices
  • new developments
    • new tools and techniques
    • new markets for old products
    • climate change
    • new species
Ceteris paribus,  maintaining "Full Vigor" would be a simple matter of measuring the change in wood volume for each tree each year and harvesting those that had passed their  individual growth rate peak.  The author claims to be operating his 200 acre forest at this point. I assume he will spell out the details of how he achieves this ideal in the chapters that follow.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I believe an incorrect interpretation of Jim Birkemeiers Chapter 2 has led to the conclusion that the most volume is the best volume, as well as the inclusion of a graphic that is not his. Reading the Full Vigor Forestry concept with better attention will bring the reader to a much more holistic view of what a healthy forest looks and feels like. The biggest volume concept is from an entirely different viewpoint, most often associated with industrial forestry practices that Jim is argueing against..

item.title: Predictably Irrational Ch13
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
You may have noticed that I have skipped writing posts on the last 11 chapters from Predictably Irrational. The authors examples of  "irrational" human behaviour did not convince. Each behaviour was explained by a "hidden force", that, once revealed, made it predictable.  Once  a behaviour has it's cause identified and its now predictable, can it be described as irrational? The author carefully explains the logic of each behaviour, then calls it illogical.  How weird is that? A better title for the book might be "Predictably Rational: finding hidden logic in our decisions". Each of the 11 chapters that I did not post about contains an interesting explanation of the (hypothesized) causes of a particular human behaviour. They are just not interesting enough  to bother writing about. A possibly apocryphal story  told about Taiichi Ohno goes  that after  he heard the Rudyard Kipling poem:

I have six honest serving men They taught me all I knew I call them What and Where and When And How and Why and Who

he replied: "We don't need all those, just keep asking why" This, the story goes, is the origin of the 5 whys method (5w method) of finding the root cause of any problem.   Predictably Irrational finds it necessary to go only a couple of whys deep to get to the "bottom" of each  puzzling human behaviour.  That's not quite deep enough.

item.title: Best American Essays: Corn-pone Opinions
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
This post kicks off a new book, "Best American Essays of the Century" Edited by Joyce Carol Oats and Robert Atwan. The first essay from this book and the topic of this post, is "Corn-pone Opinions", by Mark Twain. For those that don't have the book and want to read a copy of the essay, here it is: Text of Mark Twain's  essay: "Corn Pone Opinions" Instead of summarizing the essay, I'll stretch and twist it to suit my preferences. Twain's view of opinions  is that they  are shaped by basic survival needs--the base of Maslow's pyramid. Nowadays, our preferences are under the influence of  many competing forces. Many players are acting  to move our preferences closer their product,service, party or program. Dan Pink's recent book "Drive" identifies three forces as shaping preferences:
  1. Autonomy -- the desire to direct our own lives
  2. Mastery -- the urge to get better and better at something that matters
  3. Purpose -- the yearning to do what we do in the service of something larger than ourselves
These three forces live near the top of Maxlow's pyramid. "You tell me whar a man gits his self-actualization, en I'll tell you what his 'pinions is."

item.title: The Best American Essays: Stickeen
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
Here is the the text of John Muir's essay, Stickeen. [caption id="attachment_646" align="alignleft" width="146" caption="Stickeen, crossing the bridge"][/caption] It's the story of a wild man and a tame dog. The man was not always wild. The Great Unleashing of John Muir seems to have been triggered by an eye injury suffered while working at a carriage factory in Indianapolis, Indiana. After spending the three months following the accident in a dark room--and recovering his eyesight-- Muir did not go back to what might now be called industrial engineering, but instead he invented a new profession, that of  environmental activist. Remembering  his convalescence Muir wrote: "As soon as I got out into heaven's light … I bade adieu to mechanical inventions, determined to devote the rest of my life to the study of the inventions of God.” Muir writes in Stickeen: "But there is no estimating the wit and wisdom concealed and latent in our lower fellow mortals until made manifest by profound experiences;for it is though suffering that dogs as well as saints are developed and made perfect"  For Muir, putting himself into life and death situations grew into  a sort of spiritual practice,similar to the practice of Misogi. For me, there  is  mystery  in  why  he took the dog on his "Misogi Walk" .  By the time of the story, Muir had  experienced the spiritual rewards of putting himself in close proximity to physical danger. Did he believe that dogs can be "developed and perfected" by  "profound experiences" as well?   Muir forces Stickeen's spiritual transformation when he chooses not to carry Stikeen across, but instead, "disappeared back of a hummock". Members of the Church of Scientology have a saying: "Crossing the bridge to Ron"  (also "Crossing the bridge to total freedom"). Stickeen is a story about a Dog, crossing the snow bridge to John. I'm not the first to think that John Muir's story was more than  just a  "dog story": The ritual purification (Misogi) theme seems to be being explored in this article: From The Journal of Applied Psychoanalytic Studies

John Muir and the Erotization of Nature

Peter Loewenberg1

(1) Department of History, Southern California Psychoanalytic Institute, UCLA, USA
Abstract  John Muir (1838–1914) wrote about nature sensuously and erotically. Born in Scotland and raised by a harsh Calvinist father in rural Wisconsin, John was sadistic to animals and suffered childhood trauma which was almost lethal. As an adult he was a leader of environmental protection, founded the Sierra Club, and is responsible for Yosemite National Park and the growth of America's national park system. The author brings to bear empathic counter-transference considerations from the development of his own erotization of nature in his effort to understand Muir. The irony of national parks is their success—nature has been humanized. Where Muir's intention was to protect the wilderness, the parks now cater to millions of people who abuse, contaminate, and destroy it.
And there's a book:
John Muir's "Stickeen" & the Lessons of Nature, by Ronald H. Limbaugh

John Muir's crossing of a rugged glacier in Alaska with a little black dog slowly evolved into 'Stickeen', one of his most popular tales; but the story which saw print was much edited from Muir's original. Why did Muir struggle so with the Stickeen image and its lessons? Limbaugh examines the tale's evolution using previously under-explored annotations Muir left in his personal library. -- Midwest Book Review

item.title: Best American Essays: They All Just Went Away
item.dc:creator: George
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_716" align="alignleft" width="145" caption="Oh my, the lower classes"][/caption] "They All Just Went Away" by Joyce Carol Oates. A summary  of the  essay is here. This essay was first published in 1995 in the New Yorker. The New Yorker's abstract for the essay characterizes it as a story about abandoned houses. Here is a positive review. And here, is a much more interesting scathing one. After reading Oates' essay and the two above reviews, I am not sure what it's a story about.
